intro: Balsamus kafal, commonly known as the Armenian balsam, is a flowering plant native to the Caucasus region. It belongs to the family Malvaceae and is characterized by its hairy, glandular leaves and showy, pink to purple flowers. The plant produces a sticky, aromatic resin that has been used in traditional medicine for its anti-inflammatory properties. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in forested areas. Balsamus kafal is valued both for its ornamental appeal and its historical use in herbal remedies.
